analysis: The statement claims the speaker can secure bipartisan support for a bill by asserting that both Democratic and Republican leaders 'want it.' This relies on an unwarranted causal link between the leaders' expressed support and the bill's swift passage. The speaker assumes that because the leaders want the bill, it will automatically be signed, ignoring other factors (e.g., political negotiations, opposition, procedural hurdles). This misinterprets correlation (leaders' desire) as causation (bill passage), violating the Argument Scheme Rule (Rule 8) by committing a False Cause fallacy (category 3).
